Chapter 6, Part 2: The Heaven of the Four Kings, Part 2

Next, the bhiká¹£u, knowing the fruits of karma, having observed the ten grounds of the MÄlÄdhara Heaven, observes the ten grounds of the KÄmÄvacara Heaven, where one creates good karma oneself and experiences the fruits of happiness.
He sees with his wisdom of hearing:
The KÄmÄvacara Heaven has ten grounds.
What are the ten?
The first is called the Lotus of Practice;
The second is called the Superior Bee;
The third is called Wonderful Sound;
The fourth is called Fragrant Pleasure;
The fifth is called Wind Movement;
The sixth is called Garland Joy;
The seventh is called Universal Observation;
The eighth is called Constant Joy;
The ninth is called Loving Fragrance;
The tenth is called MÅ«rdhÄbhiá¹£ikta.
These are the ten abodes of the KÄmÄvacara Heaven, each with different karma, born in the heavens.
He sees with his wisdom of hearing:

This sentient being upholds the precepts and wholesome karma, which perfumes their mind. They take refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, and chant namo buddhaya (homage to the Buddha), taking the three refuges.

By this wholesome karma, they will eventually reach nirvana. Their goodness is inexhaustible. When this person's life ends, they will be reborn in the Heaven of the Kalavinka-footed Devas, walking on lotus flower grounds, experiencing the pleasures of the five desires.
Attached to the flavors of desire, their eyes never blink. Their body is like sunlight;

They love that ground. All the lotus flowers are the color of white elephants, adorning the ground. The flowers are always blooming. The fragrance of each lotus flower pervades a hundred yojanas, surpassing the fragrance of all other flowers.
There are bees of various colors - vaiá¸Å«rya color - emitting various sounds. The sounds of various human entertainments and music are not even a hundred-thousandth of it.
Why is it so?
The heavenly desires and heavenly sounds cannot be heard by humans.
Why is it so?
Because it is the realm of non-humans, except for the wheel-turning king and those who have transcended desire.
The faculties and powers of the wheel-turning sage king are great, and he can experience heavenly desires;
Those who have transcended desire, their eyes and other faculties are free from sorrow and joy, and therefore they can hear.
Even the sounds of animals and bees are like this, let alone the singing sounds of heavenly maidens with love and desire, which are beyond comparison.
Just as the voices of heavenly maidens are extremely delightful, so are their forms, smells, tastes, and textures. They experience countless kinds of immeasurable love and joy.

Until their good karma is exhausted, they will fall from the heavens. If they have remaining karma, they will not fall into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals, but will obtain a human body and be born into a wealthy family with abundant wealth.
Due to their remaining good causes and conditions, up to nirvana, their blessings will not be exhausted.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and contemplate the second dwelling place of the KÄmÄvacara gods.
They see with the wisdom of hearing:
The second ground is called the Joyful Ground of the Excellent Bees.
What karma do sentient beings have to be born there?
If a person has wisdom, faith, precepts, compassion, and a mind to benefit sentient beings, and makes offerings of flowers, incense, and music to Buddha stupas,

when that person's life ends, they will be born in the realm of the excellent bees in the Heaven of the Kalavinka-like Feet. They will enjoy various kinds of music, singing, dancing, games, and laughter, and experience the pleasures of play, receiving the fruits of their own karma.

They will indulge in flowers and incense, listen to the singing of celestial maidens, and immediately experience bliss. Countless celestial maidens will sing melodious songs, and the fragrance of various flowers blown by the wind will be exceptionally wonderful. They will play with celestial maidens on the peaks of Mount Sumeru, and with their ears hearing sounds, they will experience the heavenly bliss.
The bhiká¹£us, having contemplated this, praised good karma and spoke a verse, saying:
Precepts and goodness are like stairs, the power of karma gives birth to the heavens.
If a person rides this path, they can reach the place of heavenly bliss.
The four kinds of verbal karmas and the three kinds of pure bodily karmas,
The wise person rides on these seven karmas and can reach the heavens.
Upholding the precepts is the foremost joy, which wealth cannot compare to,
Wealth can be lost, but upholding the precepts is always firm and solid.
People are adorned by the precepts, and the fragrance of the precepts is always upright,
The Buddha says that pure good karma leads to rebirth in the first heavenly realm.
If a person practices good karma, they can practice in the heavens,
Like going to a place of play, receiving the foremost bliss.
The body emits a great light, illuminating the heavenly palace,
Playing in the gardens and terraces, obtained through one's own karma.
The mind is always filled with joy, receiving bliss and always at ease,
Playing in the heavenly palaces, due to the causes and conditions of upholding the precepts.
If a person well upholds the precepts and protects them in innumerable ways,
Attaining the heavenly rewards, therefore one should cultivate precepts.
Precepts are the steps, the cause and condition for attaining various pleasures.
If a person breaks the precepts, there is no place of peace and joy.
The water of pure precepts is always filled with tranquility.
Using this to bathe oneself, one receives happiness in the heavenly palace.
If one is adorned with heavenly garlands, harmoniously receiving happiness,
And playing in the heavenly palace, it is all due to good causes.
Surrounded by heavenly maidens, like the light of the sun and moon,
Receiving happiness in the heavens, it is all due to good causes.
Whatever one thinks of, one can obtain it. Having obtained it, one never loses it.
The good Dharma always increases and grows, all due to good causes.
Receiving immeasurable happiness, all always increasing and growing,
If a person upholds the precepts, they will attain such happiness.
If a person always practices goodness, he will be respected by the king.
Goodness is the supreme adornment, therefore one should practice precepts.
Good people are always disciplined, and have compassion for all beings.
Always practicing giving with kindness, one can reach the heavenly realm.
Not killing any living beings, having pity and compassion for all,
Always practicing right livelihood, this person is born in the heavenly palace.
Not stealing others' wealth, always thinking of giving,
With the wisdom of tranquil faculties, this person reaches the heavenly realm.
Not committing adultery with others' spouses, always delighting in practicing the right path,
Seeking the tranquil nirvana, this person is born in the heavenly realm.
Not drinking alcohol to the point of intoxication, the intoxicated are despised by others.
The wise can abstain from alcohol, this person is born in the heavenly realm.
Upholding the precepts and practicing goodness, abandoning all evil deeds,
Able to give rise to immeasurable joy, comforting all beings.

' Thus the bhiká¹£us contemplate immeasurable joy and praise wholesome actions. The excellent bees rejoice, and countless bees emit wondrous sounds. Until the wholesome karma is exhausted, they will fall from the heavens. If there is wholesome karma, they will not fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animal realms.

If reborn among humans, they will be supremely handsome, with skillful speech and eloquence, always experiencing happiness without any afflictions, and have a long lifespan. Due to the remaining karma.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and contemplate the third dwelling place of the KÄmÄvacara gods.
They see with their wisdom of hearing:
The third place is called 'Wondrous Sounds.'
What karma causes sentient beings to be born there?
They know with their wisdom of hearing:
Those who observe precepts and make offerings to the TathÄgata with an immeasurable mind, offering jeweled canopies,

When such a person's life ends, they are born in the Heaven of Wonderful Sounds, experiencing heavenly bliss. They roam the true gold and lapis lazuli mountains, adorned with heavenly garlands and heavenly maidens, playing on the seven-jeweled mountains. Entering the Gandharva forest, anointed with fragrant powders, various tree forests, various springs, rivers, ponds, and lotuses, the forest has a light of blue, yellow, and purple colors.
Entering that forest, a fragrant breeze gently moves, and the leaves produce singing sounds. The singing sounds of asuras and gandharvas are not even a sixteenth part of it.
A gentle breeze blows and moves them, rubbing against each other and producing wonderful sounds. The sounds of the five kinds of music entertain and delight them.
Having heard the music, they are ten times more indulgent. They love the sounds and are attached to them, deceiving themselves. Smells, tastes, and textures are also like this.

Until the good karma of love is exhausted, they will fall from the heavens. If there is remaining good karma, they will not fall into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals, but will obtain a human body, love music a lot, be very wealthy, have a comfortable home, abundant grain, relatives, wife and children, a long life, and be respected by the king. This is due to remaining karma.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the fourth dwelling place of the KÄmÄvacara gods.
They see with their wisdom of hearing:
The fourth place of the KÄmÄvacara gods is called Gandharva.
What karma causes sentient beings to be born there?
They see with their wisdom of hearing:
These sentient beings anoint Buddha stupas with incense and maintain the precepts with faith.
When these people's lives end, they are born in the Gandharva heavens and experience heavenly bliss that cannot be compared to.

The food and drink they consume have the flavor of heavenly nectar, and their bodies and minds are free from distress. The sounds of the five kinds of music, heavenly garlands, and ornaments, as well as the pleasures of play, laughter, singing, and dancing, are always enjoyed together with the heavenly maidens, just like the surging waters of a mountain stream. They play and frolic on the mountain peaks.
The heavenly blue jewels, coral, amber, agate, and carnelian, as well as the various streams, rivers, springs, flower ponds, and groves of kachnar trees on the golden mountain peaks,

they see the various groves and play within them. The streams, rivers, and ponds have a delicious taste, surpassing all the flavors of JambudvÄ«pa. Born from good karma, they consume these supreme flavors and experience heavenly bliss.

Until their good karma is exhausted, they will fall from the heavens. If they have remaining good karma, they will not fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animal realms, but will obtain a human body, be born into a wealthy family, have abundant wealth and resources, and be replete with the five grains, due to their remaining karma.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the fifth dwelling place of the KÄmÄvacara gods.
They see with their wisdom of hearing:
The KÄmÄvacara gods have a fifth place called Wind-walking.
For what karma is one born in that place?
They know with their wisdom of hearing:

Those sentient beings, with faith and precepts, see the bhiká¹£u saá¹ƒgha and offer them fans, enabling them to feel cool like the cold medicinal herb called uÅ›Ä«ra, and cause the bhiká¹£us to recite the sÅ«tras.
When the lifespan of these people ends, they are born in the Wind-walking Heaven and experience heavenly bliss.

Due to good karma, fragrant winds come blowing, bringing incomparable joy. The fragrant winds of the four heavens all come to permeate it, a hundred thousand times more fragrant, cool and delightful, sometimes surpassing by one to five times.

The fragrance of the CaturmahÄrÄjika Heaven is twice as strong, the fragrance of the TrÄyastriá¹ƒÅ›a Heaven is three times as strong, the fragrance of the YÄma Heaven is four times as strong, the fragrance of the Tuá¹£ita Heaven is five times as strong, and the fragrance of the NirmÄá¹‡arati Heaven and ParanirmitavaÅ›avartin Heaven is six times as strong.
Because of the superiority of karma, the heavenly beings are also superior.

Having contemplated the good karma, the wind-traveling gods play in the forest, experiencing various fragrances and textures. The fragrances of the six heavens all enter this heaven, with the same wind power.
Why is this?
The merits of a single wind cannot be fully described. Whatever the gods think of, they obtain it all from the wind.
If they wish to hear music, the wind blows through the mountains and valleys, surpassing even the singing voices of the heavenly maidens.
If they wish to think of fragrances, up to the heavenly beings of the ParanirmitavaÅ›avartin Heaven, the combined fragrance of flowers is indescribable, wafting to this heaven.
If they wish for coolness, it is as they desire.
If they travel to other lands to see various treasures, they may go to the peak of Mount Sumeru or to a golden peak, or to a peak of JambÅ«nada gold or crystal.
In the gardens and forests, there are various flowers, fruits, flowing springs, rivers, and ponds, adorned with various birds and fragrant flowers;
in the places where various celestial maidens reside, there are immeasurable fragrances and textures, emitting wonderful sounds.
The celestial sons ride the wind to various gardens, forests, and valleys to play, as described above.

In this way, the fragrant wind enables these celestial sons to ride it to come and go, enjoying the pleasures of the five desires, amusing and entertaining each other, and playing and enjoying themselves without giving rise to jealousy or quarrelsome thoughts, all loving and enjoying each other.
Due to their own defiled karma, whether superior, middling, or inferior, they obtain corresponding rewards,
obtaining wonderful fragrant winds and being free from jealousy.

When the power of their karma is exhausted, they will fall from the heavens. The karma they have created may be superior, middling, or inferior. When their rewards are exhausted and their karma is exhausted, they will fall back.
In this way, sentient beings' karmic actions cause them to flow with their karma and transmigrate, not being born without a cause.
After that bhiká¹£u contemplated karma, he spoke a verse, saying:
Just as time is known by the sun, and plants grow by time,
One is born by the causes and conditions of karma, not without a cause.
For countless thousands of lifetimes, one is bound by the chains of karma,
The three kinds of craving are firm, binding all sentient beings.
Like honey mixed with poison, it should not be eaten,
Heavenly pleasures are also like this, with great suffering when falling.
When karma is exhausted, one is fearful and worried, leaving behind the heavenly maidens,
When falling, the great suffering and distress cannot be compared to anything.
When good karma is about to end, it is like the flame of a lamp about to go out,
Not knowing where to go, the mind gives rise to great suffering.
Burned by the poison of craving, sorrow and grief destroy the mind,
Frightened and afraid of losing their heavenly bodies.
Such are the flavors of various pleasures, the greatest deception of desire and love,
Because they cannot be abandoned, they increase great suffering and distress.
When about to fall from the heavens, the mind gives rise to great suffering and distress,
The various poisons of suffering in hell, sixteen times less than one.
All the flaming wheels,ğŸ”½The power of love binds sentient beings,
To all the perilous and evil paths.
The suffering of the gods when falling, the suffering of giving up life among humans,
Contemplating birth and death as like fire, seeing it, one is free from all desires.
If a person indulges in carelessness, that person has no liberation,
Careless and deluded by foolishness, far from nirvana.
One should be free from carelessness, carelessness is a great enemy,
Because of carelessness in the heavens, one falls into hell.
The three realms are like a revolving wheel, bound by karma, the wheel never ceases.
Therefore, abandon desire and attachment, and through detachment, attain nirvana.

' In this way, the bhiká¹£us observe the fall of the gods and, with a mind of detachment, contemplate the impermanence of the pleasures of the Wind-walking gods, which arise from the causes and conditions of karma and are not apart from impermanence.

Until the good karma of love is exhausted, they will fall from the heavens. If there is remaining good karma, they will not fall into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals, but will obtain a human body, be skilled in sea travel, become a great guide, and know well the wind routes, due to their remaining karma.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the sixth dwelling place of the KÄrÅ«á¹£a gods.
They see with their wisdom of hearing:
The sixth place of the KÄrÅ«á¹£a gods is called Scattering Flowers and Joy.
What kind of karma leads to birth in that heaven?
They see with their wisdom of hearing:

If a person who upholds the precepts has pure faith, and rectifies body, speech, and mind, and when the Sangha recites the precepts, offers various wash basins, or travels on the road or in the wilderness, fills a wash basin with pure water and offers it to people,

when that person's life ends, they are born in the Heaven of Scattering Flowers and Joy. With various music and playful sounds, they play with celestial maidens by the side of a mountain of various jewels, beryl, and Sumeru. Fragrant breezes carry various fragrances, and garlands and necklaces adorn their bodies. Flowing springs and bathing pools serve as adornments. The celestial sons and celestial maidens entertain each other and experience immeasurable bliss.
For immeasurable time, they enter a forest of flowing springs, and within that forest they experience celestial bliss.
The beryl trees have true gold leaves, and the true gold trees have beryl leaves.
Entering this forest, they are always filled with joy. Their bodies emit light, and they drink celestial nectar, due to the causes and conditions of good karma.
The finest honey wine in Jambudvipa, compared to what the celestials drink, is as bitter as wild lettuce.
The color and taste are perfect, and the fragrance pervades a full yojana.
All the birds have golden bodies, drink fragrant water, are filled with joy, and emit wonderful sounds that fill the forest.
There are many bees playing within.

All the fragrances flow from the trees, some are golden in color, some are the color of lapis lazuli, some are the color of malachite, some are the color of red pearls, and some are the color of green. They flow from the trees as fragrant rivers, called the River of Joy, two yojanas wide.
The sons and daughters of the gods play on both banks, enjoying themselves and experiencing pleasure.
The sons and daughters of the gods, having drunk, are delighted and sing, dance, and laugh.
The golden-colored lotuses have stems of lapis lazuli.

They play and sing, riding jeweled palaces, entering the great pond of the water of the eight virtues, playing and enjoying themselves, sprinkling each other. The pond is called Achi Zhijia, pure and adorned, incomparably wonderful.

The heavenly beings experience heavenly pleasures until their good karma is exhausted, and when their heavenly life ends, they do not fall into the three evil paths but attain a human body, born in a prosperous and happy country, always free from hunger and thirst, born into a wealthy family, not encountering famine, loved by the people, due to their remaining karma.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and contemplate the seventh abode of the Ká¹›mibhaká¹£a gods.
They see with their wisdom of hearing:
The seventh place of the Ká¹›mibhaká¹£a gods is called Universal Observation.
What kind of karma leads to birth there?
They know with their wisdom of hearing:

A person who observes precepts and practices good deeds, perfuming their mind with goodness, does not seek favors from sick people who violate the precepts, but with a compassionate mind gives them peace and comfort, and serves them without weariness.
When this person's life ends, they are born in the Universal Observation Heaven and experience the pleasures of the five desires.

Adorned with celestial garlands, their minds and thoughts filled with joy, they roam and play as they wish, surrounded by celestial maidens. Their majestic radiance shines like sunlight, and all the celestial beings respect and honor them.

They roam within the jeweled mountains of Mount Sumeru, wearing celestial garments and adorned with various jewels. They play as they wish, strolling in the forests, among lotus ponds, mountains, valleys, and springs, experiencing the fruits of their own karma.

Thus, they play within the celestial gardens and forests, with golden railings and numerous birds adorning them. The wind blows through nets of bells, producing wondrous sounds. The forest is called Universal Manifestation of Adornments, and its majestic radiance surpasses that of a hundred thousand suns.
Mount Sumeru is surrounded by seven mountain peaks that encircle this forest.
What are the seven?
The first is called High Mountain;
the second is called Combined Mountain;
the third is called Rain Falling;
the fourth is called Dragon Sound;
the fifth is called Loving Light;
the sixth is called Raining Jewels;
The seventh is called Star Garland.

Surrounding the forest, adorned with jeweled bells on the many trees, the heavenly maidens adorned with heavenly garlands play in the forest, their bodies shining with hundreds of thousands of lights.

When the heavenly sons see this, they indulge in the five desires. With golden lotus flowers, they enjoy each other, singing, dancing, playing, and laughing. They are not content with the wonderful sounds, colors, smells, tastes, and tactile sensations.
Thus, surrounded by thirty-six fires, they are burned by the fires and are not content.
The bhiká¹£us, having seen this, spoke a verse, saying:
The fires of craving surround them, pervading the heavens and the world.
The desires burn them, they are not free, and they are controlled by desire and delusion.
Just as fire increases dry firewood, causing the flames to blaze even more,
So it is for those who experience pleasure, the fires of craving increase even more.
Although the firewood and flames are blazing, people can all abandon them;
The fire of craving burns the world, entangled and unable to let go.
If a person crosses the river of craving, contemplates the fear of evil insects,
And attains the place of tranquility, it is because they have distanced themselves from craving and desire.
If a person escapes the net of craving, is far removed from desire and anger,
The wise person crosses over afflictions, forever leaving behind all worries and troubles.
If one gives, upholds precepts, and always thinks of the heavens in their mind,
This person defiles pure precepts, just like water mixed with poison.
Craving deceives all sentient beings, passing through billions of kalpas,
The foolish are unable to let go, driven by craving.
Sentient beings deceived by craving, still rely on craving,
Like a person carrying a heavy burden, drinking hot salty water.
Having drunk, they soon become thirsty again, with no respite for a moment,
The foolish do not think well, vainly exhausting themselves in suffering,
Therefore, one should abandon desire, for the mind of desire is difficult to subdue.
Those sentient beings bound by desire cannot escape from birth and death.
The unsurpassed, foremost bliss is the bliss of meditation, the place of enjoyment,
This bliss is the most excellent, able to see the city of nirvana.
Accomplishing the cause of supreme bliss, one will then experience the heavenly rewards of bliss,
But bound by the net of desire, one will again experience the suffering of hell.
Desire is neither good in the beginning, middle, nor end, always experiencing various sufferings and afflictions,
Desire is the root of all evil, as taught by the guide of the true Dharma.

' In this way, the bhiká¹£us observe the heavenly world, being swept away by the whirlpools of the river of desire, and the suffering of falling and dying. Having fully observed this, they give rise to disgust and detachment.

In this way, they observe everywhere the grounds inhabited by the gods, experiencing the heavenly bliss. Until the good karma of love is exhausted, they will fall from the heavens and not fall into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals.
If reborn among humans, they will be greatly wealthy, with wives, children, servants, retainers, and merchants as their relatives, due to their remaining karma.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the eighth dwelling place of the KÄmÄvacara gods.
They see with their wisdom of hearing:
The eighth place of the KÄmÄvacara gods is called Constant Joy.
Due to what karma is one born in that place?
They know with their wisdom of hearing:

If a sentient being with pure faith sees someone who has violated the law and should suffer death, bound in prison, and uses their wealth to redeem them, not for the sake of wealth, but to benefit sentient beings, with a compassionate mind, not seeking repayment,
when that person's life ends, they will be reborn in the heavens - always joyful, a hundred times more blissful than other gods, due to their superior karma.

Countless celestial maidens sing, dance, play, and laugh, providing entertainment. They play in the mountains and valleys, with rivers and springs of soft and smooth, pleasant touch, and enjoy heavenly pleasures in the gardens and forests.
The pleasures they experience are a hundred thousand million times greater than those of a wheel-turning king.
Why is this so?
Because they are born together with the celestial beings through the same karma, their bodies have no bones or flesh, nor are they defiled.
Beside Mount Sumeru, they are adorned with jeweled lotuses, celestial garlands, and celestial garments;ğŸ”½if they ascend a golden peak, their bodies become golden in color;
if they ascend a lapis lazuli peak, their bodies become the color of lapis lazuli;
if they enter a pool of water, their bodies all become the same color.
Ascending a lapis lazuli peak, their bodily radiance is like a second sun, due to the power of lapis lazuli;
if they ascend a silver peak, their bodily color is like snow, like a china rose, and all their limbs are well-proportioned and adorned.
surrounded by celestial maidens, making various kinds of music, playing in the gardens and forests, experiencing heavenly pleasures.

Thus playing, they saw from afar a garden grove with abundant trees, called the Heavenly Play Forest. Riding in a palace of rose gold, they entered the Heavenly Play Forest. The forest was soft and smooth, and the sounds of various birds harmonized in a beautiful way.

When the celestial sons entered, a bird called Heavenly Sound, born from the same karma as the celestials, because of the celestial good karma, then spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½If there are people who can create
loving and joyful good karma,ğŸ”½the karmic fruits of those people
will be accomplished and extremely splendid.
Having already attained heavenly pleasures, if one does not act recklessly,
from pleasure to a place of pleasure, one will later definitely attain nirvana.
All pleasures are impermanent, and in the end they will definitely be exhausted.ğŸ”½Do not receive these heavenly pleasures
as your own entertainment.
These heavenly pleasures are impermanent. When one's lifespan is exhausted, one will definitely fall and perish.
Having understood this truth, one should seek the path to nirvana.
All things are impermanent, the high will fall,
Those who come together will surely part, and those with life will all return to death.
All beings in the three realms, present and future,
Those who are born will surely die, there is no dharma that is permanent.
Just as the sun rises and sets, all people see it,
So it is with all births, the truth of death is always present.
Knowing thus that all dharmas arise and cease,
Do not act with a mind of heedlessness, for heedlessness is a fault more harmful than poison.
Being careful and not heedless, this is called ambrosia;
If one acts heedlessly, this is called the words of death.ğŸ”½If one is not heedless, one always attains a place of immortality;
If one acts heedlessly, one always goes down the road to death.
If a person engages in heedlessness, it is like poison or fire.
Those beings who engage in heedlessness will go to a place of suffering when their life ends.
If a person is not heedless, wherever they go they should be respected.
They will be able to reach the place of tranquility and permanently leave all heedlessness.
All pleasures will eventually come to an end, but fools do not realize this.
When they reach the time of death, everything is forgotten.
If a person loves their own body, they should practice good deeds.
Practice the joy of the Dharma as taught by the Buddha.
All things are impermanent, and in the end they lead to great suffering.
The Buddha, for the sake of sentient beings, teaches based on true reality.

When the gods hear the birds speak these verses, their minds become thoughtful, their minds become awakened, they recall the fruits of their past lives, they temporarily leave off their heedlessness, they know the light of contentment, they hold their minds and intentions without craving the five desires, and they do not engage in heedlessness.

But before long, their minds become agitated again, they become attached to the five desires, they experience the pleasures of the five desires, and until their good karma is exhausted, they will fall from the heavens when their lives end.

If they do not have bad karma, they will not fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals, but will obtain a human body, not encountering danger from the king, always experiencing happiness, not encountering many evils, due to their remaining karma.
Next, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the ninth dwelling place of the KÄmÄvacara gods.
They see with their wisdom of hearing:
The ninth place of the KÄmÄvacara gods is called Gandharva.
What karma do sentient beings have that causes them to be born there?
They see, hear, and know:

If a person upholds the precepts, has faith in the Three Jewels, and in the great field of merit of the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, offers various incense powders and ointments, makes pure offerings, uses lawfully obtained wealth to give generously, and after giving, contemplates and rejoices,
that person will, upon the end of their life, be born in the Heaven of Fragrant Enjoyment, experiencing heavenly bliss.

Their body emits light, and the five heavenly sounds constantly bring joy to their mind. For many eons, they experience the pleasures of the five senses without realizing the passage of time. Their faculties are addicted to pleasure, restless and greedy, transmigrating without beginning, never knowing contentment.

They play in gardens and forests, adorning their bodies with various flower garlands, anointed with fragrant ointments and powders, surrounded by various trees and forests, replete with light, and adorned with rivers, pools, and flowing springs.
Their mind is attached to sensual pleasures, unaware of their eventual decline.

In this way, the mind of love is deceived by the objects of desire, and they experience the pleasures of the five senses until their karma is exhausted, when they will fall from the heavens and return.

If there is good karma, one will not fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals, but will attain a human body, be born in a cool and refreshing country, not encounter chaos, warfare, or famine, and be revered by all people, due to the remaining karma.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the tenth abode of the KÄmÄvacara gods.
They see with their wisdom of hearing:
The tenth realm of the KÄmÄvacara gods is called Saá¹ƒtuá¹£ita.
